channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rare Protest in Vietnam Raises Call to Curb China
item.description: Some members of the ruling Communist Party fear that popular anger over territorial claims could bleed into a broader protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: British Parties Investigate 3 in Parliament Lobbying Sting
item.description: Two peers from Labour and one from the Ulster Unionist Party were recorded by a reporter pretending to represent a solar energy company.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Tsushima Journal: Japan-Korea Dispute Revived by Statue’s Theft
item.description: The tug of war between Japan and South Korea over a religious statue that both countries claim has revived memories of atrocities and resentments that go back centuries.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Our ancestors have faced the same ordeal between Japan and Korea for centuries,” the mayor said. In October, villagers in Tsushima discovered that someone had broken into the unguarded temple at night to steal a bronze statue.

item.title: Seven Die in Iran After Drinking Homemade Alcohol
item.description: A batch of illegally distilled alcohol has killed seven people, hospitalized dozens and blinded several others in the southern city of Rafsanjan.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: President of Palestinian Authority Appoints Next Premier
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas on Sunday appointed as his next prime minister Rami Hamdallah, who is credited with transforming a West Bank university in his tenure as its leader.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Rami Hamdallah, a university president, is to replace Salam Fayyad, who has resigned.

item.title: Hezbollah and Syria Rebels Clash on Border
item.description: The clashes, if confirmed, would represent some of the worst direct spillover fighting in Lebanon since Syria’s uprising began more than two years ago.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and HALA DROUBI
item.media:description: Rebel fighters with the Free Syrian Army rested Sunday at their base in the city of Aleppo. Rebels have recently fought Hezbollah.

item.title: Syrian Red Crescent Volunteers Sidestep a Battle
item.description: Some branches work in rebel areas and others in government-held regions, with crews in Damascus pursuing neutrality with surprising vigor.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamza, a volunteer with the Syrian Arab Red Crescent, at a blast site in Damascus. At least 17 with the group have died in the line of duty, according to an official.

item.title: China Reaps Biggest Benefits of Iraq Oil Boom
item.description: Since the toppling of Saddam Hussein, Chinese state-owned companies have poured workers and billions of dollars into Iraq to secure a steady supply of energy for China.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Basra, southeast of Baghdad, in which China has a stake. China has poured money and workers into Iraq.

item.title: Behind the Chinese Bid for Smithfield Foods
item.description: The bid for Smithfield Foods, America’s biggest pork producer, points to a type of cooperation between Wall Street and Asia’s elites that may be on the rise.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Wan Long is the chairman of Shuanghui International, a $7 billion behemoth that dominates pork processing in China.

item.title: Development Spurs Larger Fight Over Turkish Identity
item.description: For many Turks, the development of urban spaces is not so much progress as a reflection of growing autocratic ambitions by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Turkish antigovernment protesters chanted slogans from behind barriers during a clash with police officers in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: Nicolas Berggruen’s Big Dreams of Steering Europe’s Future
item.description: Globe-trotting billionaire Nicolas Berggruen, the founder of the private equity group Berggruen Holdings, is bringing his effort to overhaul democracy before the elite of Europe.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Brother’s Search Comes to Grim End in Afghanistan
item.description: The remains of two men were found outside a former American Special Forces base in Afghanistan on Saturday, shortly after two other bodies were found nearby.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SANGAR RAHIMI and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Turkey Premier Says Protests Will Not Stop Demolition Plans
item.description: Calling protesters “looters” and “bums,” Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said that plans to demolish a public park would continue, despite public opposition.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: The mood at the protests in Taksim Square was one of celebration for much of Sunday, until the police fired tear gas on protesters in the Besiktas neighborhood.

item.title: U.S. Lawmakers in Moscow in Inquiry on Boston Suspects
item.description: American lawmakers called for greater cooperation with Russia on intelligence and counterterrorism issues.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: A Contemplative Venice Biennale, With Less Financial Frenzy
item.description: Collectors, museum directors, curators and others take the temperature of contemporary art at an unusually thought-provoking Venice Biennale.
item.dc:creator: By CAROL VOGEL
item.media:credit: Casey Kelbaugh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul McCarthy’s giant doll at the Venice Biennale.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Roadblocks Limit Scope for Change
item.description: President Barack Obama revisited his reasoning for using drones and seeking to close the Guantánamo prison and limit his own military authority in a recent speech. But whether it elicits change is doubtful.
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Egyptian Court Rules Against Legislative Body
item.description: The ruling challenges the legitimacy of the only sitting house of Parliament and the body that drafted the country’s new constitution.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Filling India’s Huge Need for Vocational Training
item.description: Millions of young people are seeking hands-on instruction in market-friendly skills. Private academies offering short, practical courses are filling the gap left by formal colleges and universities.
item.dc:creator: By AMY YEE
item.media:credit: Prashanth Vishwanathan for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Kanchan Sharma, 17, left, took an English class at a Gras Academy branch. She says she learns more from the vocational school than she does from the traditional college where she is also enrolled.

item.title: Trade Schools Offer Hope for Rural Migrants in China
item.description: While newly minted university graduates face a tight job market, skilled vocational school graduates are in high demand.
item.dc:creator: By CORRINE DILLON
item.media:description: Uniformed students trained to be electricians at the BN Vocational School in Beijing.

item.title: Sunni Cleric Urges Muslims to Help Syria Rebels
item.description: Sheik Yusef al-Qaradawi, an Egyptian based in Qatar, has been called an extremist by Syrian authorities but has been influential in the uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah has committed Hezbollah to fight on behalf of Syria’s government.

item.title: Mauritania Says U.S. Sent Prisoner From Afghan Base
item.description: The prisoner, Younis al-Mauritani, suspected of being a senior member of Al Qaeda, was transferred from the American military base in Bagram to Mauritania, officials in Mauritania said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sunni-Shiite Violence Flares in Mideast in Wake of Syria War
item.description: The war is setting off a contagious sectarian conflict in Iraq and Lebanon, rekindling long-simmering tensions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Iraqi Shiites at the shrine of Sayida Zeinab in Damascus, where the Prophet Muhammad’s granddaughter is said to be buried.

item.title: Police Retreat in Istanbul as Protests Expand Through Turkey
item.description: While the protest began over plans to destroy a park, for many demonstrators it had moved beyond that to become a broad rebuke to the 10-year leadership of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer near Taksim Square in Istanbul, where the unrest expanded in its second day.

item.title: Russian Forces Detain Mayor In Dagestan
item.description: Said D. Amirov, the mayor of Dagestan’s capital, was detained in connection with the 2011 killing of a senior state investigator.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Gunmen Attack Niger Prison
item.description: The escape attempt by prisoners said to be associated with “terrorist groups” on Saturday took place at the central prison in Niger’s capital, Niamey, and two guards were killed.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
